p: Chloroquine, a close relative of hydroxychloroquine, has shown potent in vitro activity against influenza virus and other coronaviruses, including SARS-CoV-1. SARS-CoV-1 was the cause of the SARS epidemic in 2003 [ 13, 14]. In vivo studies using chloroquine in various animal models have failed to consistently translate into successful outcomes in treating these viral infections [ 3, 14]. In a randomized trial, chloroquine was ineffective at preventing influenza infection [ 15]. A comparison of chloroquine to hydroxychloroquine in vitro demonstrated that hydroxychloroquine was more effective against SAR-COV-2 [ 7]. This argues that hydroxychloroquine is a more potent agent than chloroquine for treating SARS-COV-2.
